column4: I installed a software from source using some options in configure script and now i would like to choose different options, what should i do? Just run ./configure with the desired options and then make and make install?
sounds like it would be worth a try
you could try doing a "sudo make uninstall" first if you want
can you do anything useful? then it's probably bash =)..
there is probably some kind of enviroment variable.. I don't think sh uses colours and such either
on my computer sh only uses the prompt "$"
I have a script that is sopposed to run in sh.
ok... then run it using sh? "sh scriptname.sh"
I think dash and sh are pretty compatible..if not totally compatible.. bash and sh on the other hand do some things differently

Everytime I run a configure script i get a message "[: 98: ==: unexpected operator" and the script continues but does not behave in the expect manner. I have tested this script in an other pc(fedora) and it run ok. It does not accept "=="
you've tried both bash and sh ?
yes.
then I would start looking for a new version of that script
usually one of those works.. but if both fail I don't know how to fix it from your end.. unless you want to debug that script
I will try to rplace all == by =.
sudo apt-get install build-essential
I think that does it
have you tried?
How should I do to copy?
did you try what you just wrote?
Yes, but it didn'd copy.
ok, try cp -r <dir1> <dir2>
